user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of return_directory_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
return_directory_response (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  (void) pthread_mutex_lock (&mutex);
  if (NULL == cached_directory_response)
    ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                              MHD_HTTP_INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR,
                              internal_error_response);
  else
    ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                              MHD_HTTP_OK,
                              cached_directory_response);
  (void) pthread_mutex_unlock (&mutex);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
(void) pthread_mutex_unlock (&mutex);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call is to pthread_mutex_unlock, which does not call return_directory_response. Rule 17.2 would be violated only if pthread_mutex_unlock (or any function it calls) directly or indirectly invoked return_directory_response — e.g. if pthread_mutex_unlock were replaced by a wrapper or a callback it calls invoked return_directory_response. That is not the case here.
